title: 1  1.  Overview of AI today
section: 1.2 Survey of Current AI Capabilities and Shortcomings
text:
1.2 Survey of Current AI Capabilities and Shortcomings
Artificial Intelligence, or AI, has featured very prominently in the news in recent years. Modern AI systems have been developed that can do many things that were once considered impossible for computers to do. The list below segments AI features into distinct categories. However, AI is constantly being incorporated into other systems at a rapid pace. Often an AI feature is just one part of a much larger system. Therefore, while the list below is demonstrative of AI abilities, keep in mind that these abilities are constantly being blended and incorporated into systems to the point that they might not be recognized as separate “AI” features. Some of the systems below are free to use, while others charge for their services. Specific offerings are in a constant state of flux with new services constantly appearing and existing services being modified all the time. The following list may very well be outdated by the time you read this. However, knowing that different types of AI systems exist gives you the ability to search for up to date offerings at your leisure.
An “AI model” is the underlying technology that powers the logic, reasoning and abilities of an AI. You can think of a “model” as similar to a “computer program”. Different AI “models” have different capabilities and power. Later, we will discuss some of the technical terminology that is associated with an “AI model”.

Chat systems - chatgpt is the most well known of these systems. However, there are many such systems available today. These are probably the most well known of all modern AI systems. These systems are able to carry on a running conversation. They can answer questions, give opinions, write novels, write software code, etc. We will study these types of systems in more depth later. Many of these systems have been given added features that allow them to search the web, generate images, view images and understand them, etc.
Examples: https://chatgpt.com , https://claude.ai , https://grok.com , Google’s https://gemini.google.com , https://perplexity.ai/
These types of systems are powered by “Large Language Models” or LLMs. We will discuss more about the technology that is used to create an LLM a little later.
Image generation - Generate images from text prompts. These systems can generate cartoons, photrealistic pictures, imitate styles of famous artists, etc. Some systems are more capable than others.
Examples: https://chatgpt.com, https://www.midjourney.com/, etc.
Video generation - generate videos from text prompts.
Examples: Google search for “ai video generator”
Humanoid Robots - Robots in humanoid form. These robots can currently be used for repetitive tasks such as those that are commone in factories. Large investments are being made in the techonology. Many tecnologists and business professionals predict that humanoid robots will become adept enough in the relatively near future to be used for general tasks such as general household chores, e.g. cooking, vacuuming, etc. as well as more complex tasks following after that.
Examples:
Boston Dynamics Atlas https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-e1_QhJ1EhQ ,
Tesla bot https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eCNVet_wXGA
Autonomous Systems - Use computer vision and reinforcement learning for self-driving - Tesla, Waymo. Automate delivery and logistics - drones, warehouse robots
Healthcare

Predict protein structures and assist in drug discovery - AlphaFold, Insilico

Analyze medical images and patient data for early detection - AI diagnostics systems

Finance

Identify abnormal transaction patterns - fraud detection systems

Optimize investment strategies automatically - algorithmic trading platforms

Provide automated customer support - AI chatbots

Creative Arts

Generate music from text prompts or melodies - Suno, Udio

Create and edit videos using generative AI - Runway, Pika

Education

Offer personalized tutoring, feedback, and learning support - Khanmigo, Sora

Business Productivity

Integrate AI into office tools for writing

title: 1  1.  Overview of AI today
text:
1.3 A rough definition of AI
The definition of AI has changed over the years. For example getting a computer to play chess effectively was once considered a major AI milestone. However, in 1997, IBM’s chess playing system named “Deep Blue” beat the world chess champion, Garry Kasparov. From roughly that point on, chess playing programs ceased to be viewed as AI and simply became viewed as just another computer program.
Artificial intelligence has been notoriously difficult to define. One rough definition describes it as the science of creating machines that can perform tasks previously thought to require human intelligence. This is obviously a moving target as technology advances.
crumbs: 1  1. Overview of AI today

title: 1  1.  Overview of AI today
text:
1.4 Modern AI (post 2005’ish)
In the modern era (post 2005’ish) the creation of AI systems differs from classical computer programming in a very significant way. Modern AI systems are “trained” rather than “programmed”. The vast majority, if not all, of modern AI systems have an “Artificial Neural Network” (ANN) “model” at their core. The design of an ANN is loosely patterned after structures found in the human brain. The brain is composed of billions of neurons that are intricately interconnected to each other. Connections between different neurons have different strengths. When a person learns something, processes in the brain act to strengthen or weaken these connections.
The software that underlies modern ANNs is relatively simple. The software simulates the neurons and the connections between different neurons that are found in a brain. However, the real “smarts” of a modern AI system comes from the “training” that must be done to get the “strengths” (or weights) of the connections between these artificial neurons to the ideal levels in order for the ANN to accomplish a specific goal. In order to adjust the strengths of the connections between different neurons, the ANN is “shown” numerous examples of what it is being trained for.
For example, suppose an ANN is being trained to recognize whether a picture is a cat, a dog or something else. The ANN might be shown a picture and asked if it is a (1) a cat (2) a dog or (3) something else. If the AI responds correctly, nothing is changed in the ANN. However, if the AI responds incorrectly then the “weights”, or connection strengths between the artificial neurons in the ANN, are adjusted so that the ANN is “more likely” to get the right answer the next time for the given example. The exact technique for updating the weights are pretty technical and we won’t go into them now. The important thing to know is that the changing of weights between the neurons in response to incorrect actions by the ANN is in essence what gives the AI an ability to “learn” or be “trained”. (In fact, many advances in AI are directly related to improving the process by which these connections are strengthened or weakened.)
This is similar to what happens when humans study a subject and go through many different examples to test themselves. For example if a human is being trained to recognize different grades of diamonds, every example they see of a diamond helps to train their brain to pick up on the subtle differences between different grades. The human in this example slowly learns to pick up on the subtle patterns that distinguish one grade of diamond from another. Every time the human is shown something that they didn’t expect (e.g. they graded a diamond incorrectly and then were shown the correct grade) the connections between the neurons in the human brain are adjusted to help the human pick up on the subtle patterns that differentiate diamonds of different grades. In a similar way, by being shown lots of examples, an ANN is trained to pick up on the subtle patterns that help it to accomplish its task - in this case to pick up on the subtleties that distinguish a picutre of a cat from that of a dog from that of anything else. An ANN could be trained in a similar way to recognize different grades of diamonds. All such an AI would need to be trained in this way is sufficient examples of diamonds that have already been graded correctly.
crumbs: 1  1. Overview of AI today

title: 1  1.  Overview of AI today
text:
1.5 “Deep Neural Networks” (DNN) and “Deep Learning” (DL)
Modern Artificial Neural Networks, such as those that power today’s popular commercially available AI systems, contain many, many, many artificial neurons. These artificial neurons are arranged in many, many layers of neurons. One layer of neurons is connected to the next layer which is connected to the next, etc. For this reason, these networks are often referred to as “Deep Neural Networks” (DNN). The process of training these networks is often referred to as “Deep Learning” (DL).
crumbs: 1  1. Overview of AI today

title: 1  1.  Overview of AI today
text:
1.6 Narrow AI
All modern AI models are trained with one or more specific goals in mind. For example an AI system used by the IRS could be trained to identify tax returns that appear to be fraudulent. A chess playing AI could be trained to make optimal chess moves. A video game playing AI could be trained to move in the optimal way and make optimal decisions - e.g. what objects in the game should be attacked and which should not. Engineering all of these types of AI involve some sort of training that adjusts the weights between the neurons in the ANN model of the AI. These types of AIs however are often known as “narrow AI”, ie. they are intelligent at one particular task - e.g. identifying fraudulent tax returns or playing a specific game. However, these types of AIs are not designed to tackle problems outside of the domain that they’ve been specifically trained to do.
crumbs: 1  1. Overview of AI today

title: 1  1.  Overview of AI today
text:
1.7 Artificial General Intelligence (AGI)
AGI (Artificial General Intelligence) refers to a hypothetical form of AI that can understand, learn, and apply knowledge across a wide range of tasks — much like a human. An AGI would be able to reason beyond it was trained on.
Unlike narrow AI, which excels only at specific tasks (e.g., image recognition, translation, or playing chess), an AGI would:

Transfer learning from one domain to another.
Reason abstractly and solve new problems.
Understand context and common sense.
Exhibit autonomy and adaptability comparable to human intelligence.

AGI doesn’t currently exist — it’s a goal and topic of active research and debate in AI, neuroscience, and philosophy.
crumbs: 1  1. Overview of AI today

title: 1  1.  Overview of AI today
section: 1.8 Large Language Models (LLMs) vs other types of models
text:
1.8 Large Language Models (LLMs) vs other types of models
Chat based models such as ChatGPT have achieved amazing results and often give the appearance of being truly intelligent. They seem to know about everything and seem to have “general knowledge”. However as we will see these models are technically not AGI - they are trained to do one very specific thing … given a portion of text, predict the word that will come next. More specifically these LLMs are trained to generate a probability distribution for the next word to appear after a given sequence of words.
For example, suppose I told you that someone just said:
“Joe went to the ______ …” and I asked you to assign probabilities of the next word being (a) store (b) circus (c) intelligent. It’s reasonable to say that “store” would have the highest probability as it’s very common for people to go to a store, “circus” would have a somewhat lower probabability as it’s not as common for people to go to a circus and “intelligent” would have a very low probability, as it’s not quite clear what could be meant by “Joe went to the intelligent …”.
However, suppose I told you that someone just said
The training data for these chat systems include vast amounts of printed text. It’s often said that these systems are trained on the entire Internet. While that might not be exactly accurate, it is a good way to conceptualize the real story. In actuality modern commercial LLMs are trained on massive, diverse text datasets that include:

Public web content – websites, articles, forums, and open data sources.
Books and academic texts – digitized literature and research papers.
Code repositories – for models that handle programming (e.g., GitHub data).
Licensed or proprietary datasets – curated high-quality text obtained legally.
Human feedback data – conversations or task examples used for fine-tuning via reinforcement learning from human feedback (RLHF).

These datasets can total trillions of words. Training involves adjusting billions of model parameters to predict the next word in a sequence — learning language, style, and reasoning patterns from the data. Several common large-scale datasets are used (or adapted) for training or pretraining LLMs. Examples include:

The Pile – 825 GB of diverse text (academic papers, books, web content, code).
Common Crawl – a regularly updated scrape of the public web, used by most major models.
C4 (Colossal Clean Crawled Corpus) – a cleaned, English-focused subset of Common Crawl.
Wikipedia – high-quality encyclopedic text for factual grounding.
Books datasets – e.g., Books1/Books2 (used internally by OpenAI and others).
Github/code datasets – for code-capable models like Codex or Gemini Code.

Commercial labs often combine public, licensed, and proprietary corpora, cleaning and filtering them heavily to remove low-quality, duplicate, or unsafe content.
crumbs: 1  1. Overview of AI today

title: 1  1.  Overview of AI today
section: 1.9 Other methods of training an AI
text:
1.9 Other methods of training an AI
In the last section we discussed a learning technique where the AI is shown problems for which the answers are already known. This is generally known as “supervised learning”. Another popular method of training an AI involves the AI learning from trial and error using a method known as “reinforcement learning”.
Reinforcement learning (RL) is a type of machine learning where an agent learns by interacting with an environment and receiving feedback in the form of rewards or penalties.
In simple terms:

The agent takes an action in a situation.
The environment responds with a new situation and a reward (positive or negative).
Over time, the agent learns a policy — a strategy for choosing actions that maximize total reward.

It’s modeled on behavioral psychology: trial, error, and feedback. For example, a robot might learn to walk by trying movements, falling (negative reward), and staying upright longer (positive reward).
Mathematically, RL often uses methods like Q-learning or policy gradients to estimate which actions lead to the best long-term outcomes.
In short, RL is about learning from consequences, not from explicit instruction or labeled examples.
crumbs: 1  1. Overview of AI today

title: 1  1.  Overview of AI today
text:
1.10 Shortcomings of modern AI systems
Artificial Intelligence (AI) has achieved impressive results across domains such as natural language processing (NLP), computer vision, and generative content creation. Modern models can summarize long texts, generate code, compose music, and even create photorealistic images.
However, limitations persist-AI struggles with reasoning, factual accuracy, long-term context retention, and transparency in decision-making. Bias and hallucination remain active research challenges.

AI is increasingly automating analytics pipelines: - Data prep: PandasAI, AutoML, Databricks Copilot
- Visualization: Tableau’s AI Insights, Power BI Copilot

title: 1  1.  Overview of AI today
section: 1.13 Running AI Models Locally vs. Remotely
text:
1.13 Running AI Models Locally vs. Remotely

Locally: Better privacy and control; limited by hardware (GPU, RAM).

Remotely (Cloud): Scalability and access to powerful infrastructure; may involve higher latency and cost.
Hybrid setups allow on-device inference with optional cloud extensions.
crumbs: 1  1. Overview of AI today

title: 1  1.  Overview of AI today
text:
1.14 Privacy and Security Concerns
Key issues include: - Data leakage during prompt submission
- Model inversion attacks
- Unintended data retention by third-party APIs
Responsible developers anonymize inputs, use local models for sensitive data, and follow compliance frameworks like GDPR and HIPAA.
crumbs: 1  1. Overview of AI today

title: 1  1.  Overview of AI today
text:
1.15 Legal and Ethical Considerations
Topics include: - Copyright: AI-generated works and training data ownership
- Accountability: Who is responsible for model outputs?
- Bias and Fairness: Ensuring equitable results across demographics
Ethical AI development involves transparency, reproducibility, and human oversight.
crumbs: 1  1. Overview of AI today

title: 1  1.  Overview of AI today
text:
1.16 Expert Projections on AI’s Trajectory
Analysts predict: - Short-term (1–3 years): Broader multimodality, longer context windows, AI-assisted software engineering.
- Medium-term (3–7 years): More autonomous agents, integrated reasoning systems, and cross-domain synthesis.
AI is expected to become more context-aware and energy-efficient.
crumbs: 1  1. Overview of AI today

title: 1  1.  Overview of AI today
text:
1.17 Context Length Issues
Models have a maximum “context window”-the amount of text they can process at once.
When exceeded, older parts of a conversation or codebase are forgotten. Chunking, summarization, and retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) mitigate this.
crumbs: 1  1. Overview of AI today

title: 1  1.  Overview of AI today
text:
1.18 Prompting - Best Practices

Be explicit: Provide role, goal, and format.

Use structured inputs: Lists, delimiters, and examples.

Iterate: Refine prompts based on output.

Employ system prompts to steer tone and expertise.

Document prompts for reproducibility.
crumbs: 1  1. Overview of AI today

title: 1  1.  Overview of AI today
text:
1.19 Key Definitions

1.19.1 Machine Learning
The process of getting computers to recognize patterns in data by training computer “models” with existing data.

Two Main Types:

Predictive Analytics - Models learn to recognize patterns in training data so they can identify those same patterns in new, unseen data

Example: Email spam detection, weather forecasting, stock price prediction

Descriptive Analytics - Analyzing existing data using computer models to understand what happened

Example: Clustering models that separate data into naturally occurring categories, allowing analysts to discover hidden patterns and make meaning from each group





1.19.2 Deep Learning
A subset of machine learning that uses Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs) to mimic the structure and function of the human brain.

Uses multiple layers of interconnected nodes (neurons)
Particularly effective for complex pattern recognition tasks
Powers most modern AI breakthroughs including LLMs



1.19.3 Large Language Models (LLMs)
AI systems trained on vast amounts of text data to understand and generate human-like language.

Popular LLM Platforms:

OpenAI: ChatGPT, GPT-4
Anthropic: Claude.ai
Google: Gemini.com
Meta: Llama models (available through Ollama)
xAI: Grok (integrated with X/Twitter)




1.19.4 Generative AI (GenAI)
AI systems that can create new content across various media types.

Applications:

Text Generation: ChatGPT, Claude, writing assistants
Image Generation: Midjourney, DALL-E, Stable Diffusion
Video Generation: Sora (OpenAI), Runway ML
Code Generation: GitHub Copilot, Cursor
Scientific Applications: Molecular structure design for drug discovery




1.19.5 Reinforcement Learning
A machine learning approach where models learn by interacting with an environment and receiving feedback (rewards/penalties) based on their actions.

Key Examples:

Game-playing AI (Chess, Go, Atari games)
Robotics and autonomous systems
Training ChatGPT through human feedback (RLHF - Reinforcement Learning from Human Feedback)
crumbs: 1  1. Overview of AI today

1.20.1 Geoffrey Hinton

“The Godfather of AI”
Pioneer of modern deep learning and neural networks
Won Turing Award (2018) and Nobel Prize in Physics (2024)
Former Google researcher, now advocates for AI safety



1.20.2 Ilya Sutskever

Co-founder and former Chief Scientist at OpenAI
Key contributor to transformer architecture (foundation of modern LLMs)
Currently working on AI safety research



1.20.3 Demis Hassabis

CEO of Google DeepMind
Founded DeepMind (acquired by Google in 2014)
Won Nobel Prize in Chemistry (2024) for AlphaFold protein structure prediction
Led development of AlphaGo, first AI to beat world champion in Go



1.20.4 Sam Altman

CEO of OpenAI
Co-founded OpenAI with Elon Musk and others (2015)
Led OpenAI’s transition from non-profit to capped-profit structure



1.20.5 Elon Musk

Co-founded OpenAI but left the board in 2018 due to conflicts
Founded xAI (2023) to create “maximum truth-seeking AI”
Owns X (formerly Twitter), which integrates with Grok AI

title: 1  1.  Overview of AI today
text:
1.21 How LLM Technology Works

1.21.1 Core Mechanism: Next-Token Prediction

LLMs are fundamentally predictive models that calculate probability distributions for the next word (token) in a sequence
They don’t “understand” language in human terms, but excel at predicting statistically likely continuations



1.21.2 Context Window

The context refers to all the text that precedes the word being generated
Modern LLMs can process contexts of 100K+ tokens (roughly 75K+ words)
Larger context windows enable better understanding of long documents and conversations



1.21.3 Training Process

Pre-training: Model learns patterns from massive text datasets
Fine-tuning: Model is refined for specific tasks
RLHF: Human feedback shapes model behavior and safety
crumbs: 1  1. Overview of AI today

title: 2  2.  Intro to Coding with an LLM
text:
2.1 What Is AI-Assisted Development?
LLMs can act as pair programmers-explaining concepts, debugging, and generating code snippets.
Developers should verify AI-generated code and understand its logic, using LLMs as accelerators, not replacements.
crumbs: 2  2. Intro to Coding with an LLM

title: 2  2.  Intro to Coding with an LLM
text:
Using AI tools (e.g., GitHub Copilot, ChatGPT, Tabnine) to help write, debug, and document code.
Works through natural language prompts → AI generates suggestions.
Goal: Accelerate productivity, not replace developers.


2.1.1 Benefits

Faster prototyping: Generate boilerplate & starter code.
Improved productivity: Offload repetitive coding tasks.
Learning aid: Explore unfamiliar libraries, frameworks, or languages.
Debugging help: Suggest fixes, highlight possible errors.
Documentation: Generate comments, READMEs, or summaries.



2.1.2 Limitations

Not always correct: AI can produce plausible but wrong code.
Security risks: May introduce vulnerabilities.
Bias & licensing: Trained on public data → risk of copyright/ethical issues.
Context gaps: AI may miss project-specific conventions or requirements.
crumbs: 2  2. Intro to Coding with an LLM

title: 2  2.  Intro to Coding with an LLM
text:
2.2 Essential Technologies for AI-Assisted Development

2.2.1 Markdown

Lightweight markup language for formatting text
Standard for documentation, README files, and AI-generated content
Easy to read in plain text and renders beautifully when formatted



2.2.2 Command Line Interface (CLI) / Bash

Essential for efficient development workflows
Many of the more advanced AI coding tools integrate with terminal/command line
Bash scripting automates repetitive development tasks
Git version control operates primarily through CLI



2.2.3 Additional Development Tools

Version Control: Git and GitHub for code management
Package Managers: npm (Node.js), pip (Python), cargo (Rust)
Containerization: Docker for consistent development environments
Cloud Platforms: AWS, Google Cloud, Azure for deployment
crumbs: 2  2. Intro to Coding with an LLM

title: 2  2.  Intro to Coding with an LLM
text:
2.3 AI-Assisted Development Workflow

2.3.1 1. Planning & Architecture

Use AI to brainstorm project structure
Generate technical specifications and documentation
Create user stories and feature requirements



2.3.2 2. Code Generation

AI can write functions, classes, and entire modules
Generate boilerplate code and configuration files
Create test cases and documentation



2.3.3 3. Debugging & Optimization

AI analyzes error messages and suggests fixes
Code review and improvement recommendations
Performance optimization suggestions



2.3.4 4. Learning & Documentation

AI explains complex code and concepts
Generates comprehensive documentation
Creates tutorials and learning materials
crumbs: 2  2. Intro to Coding with an LLM

title: 2  2.  Intro to Coding with an LLM
text:
2.4 Best Practices for AI-Assisted Development

2.4.1 Effective Prompting

Be specific: Provide context, requirements, and constraints
Iterate: Refine prompts based on AI responses
Verify: Always review and test AI-generated code



2.4.2 Maintain Human Oversight

Understand the code before implementing
Test thoroughly: AI can introduce subtle bugs
Security review: AI may suggest insecure practices



2.4.3 Continuous Learning

Stay updated: AI tools evolve rapidly
Experiment: Try different AI models and approaches
Share knowledge: Collaborate and learn from others’ experiences
crumbs: 2  2. Intro to Coding with an LLM

title: 2  2.  Intro to Coding with an LLM
text:
2.5 Other material

2.5.1 Best Practices

Always review AI-generated code.
Use AI for prototyping, scaffolding and exploration, not final production code.
Keep security in mind: sanitize input, check dependencies.
Iterate with prompts: refine instructions for better results.
Learn from it: treat AI as a teaching partner, not just a shortcut.



2.5.2 Buzzwords for best practices

Context Engineering
Spec Driven Development



2.5.3 Typical Workflows

Code completion: AI predicts the next lines.
Code generation: Write natural language → AI writes code.
Refactoring: Ask AI to improve readability or performance.
Explaining code: Have AI summarize or translate complex code.
Testing: Generate test cases & unit tests automatically.



2.5.4 The Human in the Loop

You remain responsible for correctness, quality, and ethics.
AI is a tool, not a replacement.
Think of AI like a junior developer: fast, but needs supervision.



2.5.5 Spec driven development

Github specify product
BMAD Method

follows Agile Engineering methods
praised by many in the space

numerous others



2.5.6 Key Takeaways

AI can speed up development, but requires critical oversight.
Use it to amplify creativity and productivity, not as a crutch.
The best developers will know when to trust AI—and when not to.

title: 3  3.  How to install Cursor on your computer
text:
3.1 What is an Integrated Development Environment (IDE)
Cursor is an AI powered “Integrated Development Environment” (IDE) for developing software.
An “IDE” is a single program that has many different tools embedded inside of it to aid in creating programs. For example RStudio is an IDE that is focused on developing R programs. RStudio contains
Cursor is similar to RStudio in that it contains many different tools to help with creating programs. However, Cursor is not focused on a single language. You can develop programs in Cursor for many different languages, including, Python, R, Java, C++, JavaScript, TypeScript, Ruby, Rust, etc. etc. etc.
One of Cursor’s primary features is that it is integrated extensively with AI tools. From within the Cursor program, you can ask AI to help write your program, fix bugs, suggest approaches for solving a problem, brainstorm about the code, reorganize the code, etc. etc. etc.
crumbs: 3  3. How to install Cursor on your computer

many, many other features that aid in developing R programs

title: 3  3.  How to install Cursor on your computer
section: 3.2 Desktop version of Cursor is not the same as the online version
text:
3.2 Desktop version of Cursor is not the same as the online version
It is important to understand that the Cursor program is primarily a desktop application, intended to be installed on your computer (Windows, Mac, Linux). There is also a tool on the web at https://cursor.com /agents. The website tool is very different from the version of Cursor that is installed on your computer. This can be confusing.
The version of Cursor that is installed on your computer is the primary tool for creating software programs with AI. The tool found online at https://cursor.com/agents serves a slightly different purpose. We will first focus on the Desktop version of Cursor that is installed on your computer. We will revisit the product at https://cursor.com/agents later in the semester.
crumbs: 3  3. How to install Cursor on your computer

title: 3  3.  How to install Cursor on your computer
section: 3.3 How to download and install Cursor on your computer
text:
3.3 How to download and install Cursor on your computer
The following is what you’ll see when you visit https://cursor.com for the first time:

Notice that in the upper right hand corner of the screen there are TWO buttons:

Sign In
Download

You should press the “Download” button and proceed to download and install the desktop version of Cursor on your computer.
If you incorrectly pressed the “Sign In” button you will be signed into the web version of Cursor. Note that this is not what you should be doing. You might be directed to https://cursor.com/dashboard or to https://cursor.com/agents. You will see a webpage similar to the following:

If that happens, please sign out of the website. To do so, click on the icon for your user in the upper right hand corner of the webpage and choose “log out”. After you’ve logged out, please return to https://cursor.com and then press the Download button and install the Desktop version of the software.
crumbs: 3  3. How to install Cursor on your computer

title: 3  3.  How to install Cursor on your computer
text:
3.4 Next Steps
We will be going over in class how to use the different features of Cursor. If you want to explore a little by yourself the ctrl-shift-P key can be helpful. This hotkey lets you search through all of the different settings and features within cursor. Many people like changing the default color theme from a dark theme to a light (bright) theme. To do so, press ctrl/cmd-alt-P and type “color theme” (without the quotes). Then press “Preferences: color theme” to allow you to choose a new theme.
There is a lot that you can do with cursor. We will cover this in more depth in class.

title: 4  4.  Intro to Bash (and CLIs)
text:
4.1 What are the benefits of using a CLI (Command Line Interpreter)?
The “user interface” on a computer is the mechanism with which users instruct the computer to do specific things. Non-technical users interact with computers by using the mouse to click and drag items on the screen. These users are using the “Graphical User Interface” (GUI) of the computer (see below for more info). Most people are not even aware that there is a way to do just about everything on a computer without even touching a mouse.
Technical users (e.g. programmers, computer system administrators, etc) often use a totally different mechanism to interact with the computer. They use a special program (known as a CLI or “command line interpreter”) to type special “commands” to do different things on the computer. For example, a technically inclined user, might type the command mkdir progressReports to create a new folder named progressReports. By contrast, non-technical users might right-click in the FileExplorer (Windows) or Finder (Mac) programs and choose “new file” from the menu that is displayed.
There many, many (hundreds?) of different commands that can be typed in the CLI program. Each command is used to accomplish something specific on the computer. Using a CLI is a skill, similar to programming, that takes some time to master. It is obviously much easier for a typical computer user to use the GUI on the computer. Most people aren’t even aware there is another way. Why then would technical users use a Comamnd Line Interface at all?
It takes time and practice to master how to control a computer by using a CLI (command line interface). However, for technical users, the time spent learning how to use a CLI is time well spent. For the following reasons:
crumbs: 4  4. Intro to Bash (and CLIs)

title: 4  4.  Intro to Bash (and CLIs)
text:
Many tools that are used in software development only have a CLI commands with no equivalent GUI program.
Once you have learned and mastered the numerous CLI commands, it can become trivial to accomplish very sophisticated results with much less effort than would be required if only using a GUI. A technical user might type the command mv project1/*2025* project2 to move all files with 2025 in their name from the project1 folder to the project2 folder. If there are 100 files in the project1 folder and 50 of those files have 2025 somewhere in their name, a typical non-technical user might take several minutes or longer to find each of the desired files and drag them to the correct folder. By contrast, typing the above command in the CLI and pressing ENTER takes a few seconds. This is a simple example. The general rule though is that for people who have mastered the CLI commands are able to control the computer in a much quicker and more efficient way.
It is relatively easy to “automate” the CLI commands. You can collect numerous CLI commands in a single file, known as a “script file”. Then you can direct the CLI to run all of the commands that are saved in the script file at once. This opens the door to writing script files that can be reused at different times or on different computers to accomplish a repetitive task.
crumbs: 4  4. Intro to Bash (and CLIs)

title: 4  4.  Intro to Bash (and CLIs)
section: 4.3 What is a Graphical User Interface (GUI)?
text:
4.3 What is a Graphical User Interface (GUI)?
The “user interface” on a computer is the mechanism with which the computer user instructs the computer to do specific things. Non-technical users interact with a computer via the “Graphical User Interface” of the computer. For example, all of the following are parts of the GUI (Graphical User Interface) on Mac and Windows

double clicking on icons to open a program or to open a file in the appropriate program
clicking/dragging on a titlebar to move a window to a different location
clicking on a filename in Windows Explorer or Mac Finder and dragging the file to different folder to either move or copy the file to the other folder
clicking on the “File” menu in Excel to get to the menu choices for opening/creating/etc files
clicking on different pictures and text to get something to happen
etc.

All of the above features rely heavily on using the mouse to interact with “pictures” or text that appear on the computer screen.
crumbs: 4  4. Intro to Bash (and CLIs)

title: 4  4.  Intro to Bash (and CLIs)
section: 4.4 What is a CLI and Why Should You Care?
text:
4.4 What is a CLI and Why Should You Care?
A CLI (Command Line Interface) is a way to interact with your computer using text commands instead of clicking on icons and buttons. Think of it like texting your computer instructions instead of pointing at things.
When people talk about “the command line” or “the terminal,” they’re usually referring to a CLI. It might look intimidating at first—just a black or white screen with text—but once you learn a few commands, it becomes a powerful way to work with files and folders on your computer.

4.4.1 What is Bash?
Bash (which stands for “Bourne Again Shell”) is one of the most popular CLIs. It’s the standard on most Linux systems and Mac computers. When you type commands in Bash, you’re essentially having a conversation with your computer in a special language it understands.


4.4.2 How to Access Bash on Different Systems
On Mac: Open the Terminal application. You can find it by pressing Cmd + Space and typing “Terminal”, or by going to Applications → Utilities → Terminal.
On Windows: Windows doesn’t come with Bash by default. You have a few options:

Git Bash - A lightweight option that comes with Git. It’s perfect for basic Bash commands and is what we recommend for getting started.
WSL2 (Windows Subsystem for Linux) - A full Linux environment inside Windows. This is more advanced and beyond the scope of this guide.

Important Note for Windows Users: Windows has its own native CLIs called CMD (Command Prompt) and PowerShell. These are conceptually similar to Bash—they let you type commands to control your computer—but the actual commands are different. For example, in Bash you use ls to list files, but in PowerShell you use Get-ChildItem or dir. This guide focuses on Bash commands.
crumbs: 4  4. Intro to Bash (and CLIs)

title: 4  4.  Intro to Bash (and CLIs)
text:
4.5 Our Sample File Structure
Throughout this guide, we’ll use the same example file structure. Here’s what it looks like.
You can download a zip file that contains these files here.
Download the practice files
bash-tutorial-files/
├── README.txt
├── documents/
│   ├── notes/
│   │   ├── ideas.txt
│   │   └── meeting-notes.txt
│   └── reports/
│       ├── annual-summary.txt
│       └── quarterly-report.txt
├── music/
│   ├── song1.mp3
│   └── song2.mp3
├── pictures/
│   ├── family.jpg
│   └── vacation.jpg
└── projects/
    ├── data-analysis/
    │   ├── analysis.py
    │   └── data.csv
    └── website/
        ├── index.html
        └── styles.css

4.5.1 How to Read This Tree Structure

Lines with / at the end are directories (folders)
Lines without / are files
The indentation shows which items are inside which folders
For example, ideas.txt is inside the notes/ folder, which is inside the documents/ folder

Note: A directory is just another word for a folder. Computer people often use “directory” instead of “folder,” but they mean the same thing!


4.5.2 Download the Practice Files
We’ve prepared a zip file with all these folders and files so you can follow along. Download and extract bash-tutorial-files.zip to a location on your computer (like your Desktop or Documents folder).
crumbs: 4  4. Intro to Bash (and CLIs)

title: 4  4.  Intro to Bash (and CLIs)
text:
4.6 Understanding Files and Folders
One important thing to understand: files can be arranged in different folders, which means two different files can have the same name as long as they’re in different folders.
For example, you could have: - projects/website/README.txt - projects/data-analysis/README.txt
These are two completely different files, even though they’re both named README.txt. They’re in different locations (different folders), so there’s no conflict.
crumbs: 4  4. Intro to Bash (and CLIs)

title: 4  4.  Intro to Bash (and CLIs)
text:
4.7 Your Home Directory
Every user account on a computer has a special folder called the home directory. This is your personal space where you keep your files and folders.

On Mac/Linux: Your home directory is usually /Users/yourusername or /home/yourusername
On Windows (with Git Bash): It’s usually C:\Users\yourusername

When you open a new terminal, you usually start in your home directory automatically. Think of it as your “home base” in the file system.
crumbs: 4  4. Intro to Bash (and CLIs)

title: 4  4.  Intro to Bash (and CLIs)
text:
4.8 The Bash Prompt
When you open your terminal, you’ll see something called the prompt. It might look like:
user@computer:~$
or
MacBook-Pro:~ username$
or just
$
Don’t panic if yours looks different! The prompt varies depending on your system settings, but it all works the same way. The prompt is just Bash’s way of saying “I’m ready for your next command!”
The $ symbol at the end is the most important part—it signals that you can type a command. When you see example commands in this guide or online, you’ll often see them written with a $ at the start. Don’t type the $—it’s just showing you where the prompt is.
crumbs: 4  4. Intro to Bash (and CLIs)

title: 4  4.  Intro to Bash (and CLIs)
section: 4.9 Your First Commands: Where Am I?
text:
4.9 Your First Commands: Where Am I?

4.9.1 The pwd Command (Print Working Directory)
The first thing you usually want to know is: where am I in the file system right now? That’s what pwd does—it shows you your current location.
$ pwd
Output:
/home/username/Desktop/bash-tutorial-files
This output is called a full path (or “absolute path”). Let’s break it down:

It starts with / which represents the very top (root) of your entire file system
Each / separates folder names
Reading left to right shows the path from the root to where you are now
This path says: “Start at the root, go into home, then username, then Desktop, then bash-tutorial-files”

Think of a full path like a complete street address: “123 Main Street, Springfield, IL, USA” gives you everything you need to find a location. Similarly, /home/username/Desktop/bash-tutorial-files gives you everything you need to find this folder.
crumbs: 4  4. Intro to Bash (and CLIs)

title: 4  4.  Intro to Bash (and CLIs)
text:
4.10 Looking Around: The ls Command
Now that you know where you are, let’s see what’s in this location! The ls command lists the files and folders in your current directory.
$ ls
Output:
README.txt  documents  music  pictures  projects
Great! We can see there’s a README.txt file and four folders: documents, music, pictures, and projects.

4.10.1 Command Options: Making ls More Useful
Most Bash commands have options (also called “flags”) that modify their behavior. Options usually start with a dash -.
Let’s try ls with the -l option, which shows the “long” format with more details:
$ ls -l
Output:
total 4
-rw-r--r-- 1 username username    0 Oct 22 12:00 README.txt
drwxr-xr-x 4 username username 4096 Oct 22 12:00 documents
drwxr-xr-x 2 username username 4096 Oct 22 12:00 music
drwxr-xr-x 2 username username 4096 Oct 22 12:00 pictures
drwxr-xr-x 4 username username 4096 Oct 22 12:00 projects
Now we see much more information! The first column shows permissions, the numbers are file sizes in bytes, and we see dates and times. Lines starting with d are directories (folders), while lines starting with - are regular files.
Let’s add the -t option, which sorts by time (newest first):
$ ls -l -t
Output:
total 4
drwxr-xr-x 4 username username 4096 Oct 22 12:00 projects
drwxr-xr-x 2 username username 4096 Oct 22 12:00 pictures
drwxr-xr-x 2 username username 4096 Oct 22 12:00 music
drwxr-xr-x 4 username username 4096 Oct 22 12:00 documents
-rw-r--r-- 1 username username    0 Oct 22 12:00 README.txt
Now add -r to reverse the sort order (oldest first):
$ ls -l -t -r
Output:
total 4
-rw-r--r-- 1 username username    0 Oct 22 12:00 README.txt
drwxr-xr-x 4 username username 4096 Oct 22 12:00 documents
drwxr-xr-x 2 username username 4096 Oct 22 12:00 music
drwxr-xr-x 2 username username 4096 Oct 22 12:00 pictures
drwxr-xr-x 4 username username 4096 Oct 22 12:00 projects


4.10.2 Options Can Be Combined and Reordered!
Here’s something cool: the order of options doesn’t matter. These all do the same thing:
$ ls -l -t -r
$ ls -r -t -l
$ ls -t -r -l
Even better, you can combine single-letter options into one:
$ ls -ltr
This is exactly the same as ls -l -t -r! It’s just shorter to type. So -ltr means “long format, sorted by time, reversed order.”
crumbs: 4  4. Intro to Bash (and CLIs)

title: 4  4.  Intro to Bash (and CLIs)
section: 4.11 Creating New Folders: The mkdir Command
text:
4.11 Creating New Folders: The mkdir Command
The mkdir command lets you make a directory (create a new folder). Let’s create a new folder called temp:
$ mkdir temp
Output:
(no output - success is silent!)
In Bash, many commands don’t print anything when they succeed. No news is good news! Let’s verify it worked:
$ ls
Output:
README.txt  documents  music  pictures  projects  temp
There’s our new temp folder!
crumbs: 4  4. Intro to Bash (and CLIs)

title: 4  4.  Intro to Bash (and CLIs)
text:
4.12 Moving Around: The cd Command
The cd command lets you change directory—that is, move to a different folder. Let’s go into the documents folder:
$ cd documents
Output:
(no output)
Again, no output means success. Let’s verify where we are now:
$ pwd
Output:
/home/username/Desktop/bash-tutorial-files/documents
Perfect! We’re now inside the documents folder. Let’s see what’s in here:
$ ls
Output:
notes  reports
We can see the notes and reports folders.

4.12.1 Using Full Paths with cd
You can jump directly to any location using a full path. Let’s go to the website folder:
$ cd /home/username/Desktop/bash-tutorial-files/projects/website
$ pwd
Output:
/home/username/Desktop/bash-tutorial-files/projects/website


4.12.2 Going Up One Level: The .. Shortcut
What if we want to go back up to the parent folder? The parent folder is the one that contains your current folder. For example, if you’re in website, the parent is projects.
Bash has a special shortcut: .. (two periods) means “the parent directory.” Let’s try it:
$ cd ..
$ pwd
Output:
/home/username/Desktop/bash-tutorial-files/projects
We moved up one level from website to projects! Let’s go up again:
$ cd ..
$ pwd
Output:
/home/username/Desktop/bash-tutorial-files
Now we’re back at the top of our tutorial files. You can even chain .. together. To go up two levels at once:
$ cd documents/reports
$ pwd
Output:
/home/username/Desktop/bash-tutorial-files/documents/reports
Now let’s go up two levels:
$ cd ../..
$ pwd
Output:
/home/username/Desktop/bash-tutorial-files
The path ../.. means “go up one level, then go up another level.”


4.12.3 Going Home
There are quick shortcuts to jump to your home directory:
$ cd ~
or just
$ cd
Both take you straight to your home directory, no matter where you are!
crumbs: 4  4. Intro to Bash (and CLIs)

title: 4  4.  Intro to Bash (and CLIs)
section: 4.13 Getting Help: How to Learn More About Commands
text:
4.13 Getting Help: How to Learn More About Commands
You don’t need to memorize everything! Bash has built-in help for most commands.

4.13.1 The --help Option
Many commands support a --help option that shows you how to use them:
$ ls --help
Output:
Usage: ls [OPTION]... [FILE]...
List information about the FILEs (the current directory by default).
Sort entries alphabetically if none of -cftuvSUX nor --sort is specified.

Mandatory arguments to long options are mandatory for short options too.
  -a, --all                  do not ignore entries starting with .
  -A, --almost-all           do not list implied . and ..
  -l                         use a long listing format
  -r, --reverse              reverse order while sorting
  -t                         sort by time, newest first
  -S                         sort by file size, largest first
  -h, --human-readable       with -l, print sizes in human readable format
  ...


4.13.2 Understanding Help Output
Let’s break down what this help text means:

Short options: Single letters with one dash, like -l, -t, -r

These can be combined: -ltr is the same as -l -t -r

Long options: Full words with two dashes, like --all, --help, --human-readable

These usually can’t be combined
They’re more readable but take longer to type


For example, these do the same thing:
$ ls -a
$ ls --all


4.13.3 Man Pages: The Full Manual
If a command doesn’t have --help, or if you want even more detailed information, you can look up man pages (manual pages).
In a full Bash environment (like on Mac or Linux), you can type:
$ man ls
This opens a detailed manual page for the ls command. You can navigate with arrow keys and press q to quit.
Note: Some lightweight Bash environments (like Git Bash on Windows) might not have man pages installed. If man doesn’t work, you can search online for “bash ls man page” or “man ls” and find the documentation online.
crumbs: 4  4. Intro to Bash (and CLIs)

title: 4  4.  Intro to Bash (and CLIs)
text:
4.14 Working with Files and Folders
Now let’s learn how to create, copy, move, and delete files and folders.

4.14.1 Creating Empty Files: The touch Command
The touch command creates an empty file or updates the timestamp of an existing file:
$ touch test.txt
$ ls
Output:
README.txt  documents  music  pictures  projects  temp  test.txt
We created a new empty file called test.txt!


4.14.2 Copying Files: The cp Command
The cp command copies files or folders. The syntax is: cp source destination
Let’s copy our test file:
$ cp test.txt test-copy.txt
$ ls
Output:
README.txt  documents  music  pictures  projects  temp  test-copy.txt  test.txt
Now we have both the original test.txt and a copy called test-copy.txt.
To copy a file into a folder:
$ cp test.txt documents/
$ ls documents/
Output:
notes  reports  test.txt
The test.txt file has been copied into the documents folder!
To copy an entire folder (directory) and all its contents, use the -r option (which stands for “recursive”):
$ cp -r documents documents-backup
$ ls
Output:
README.txt  documents  documents-backup  music  pictures  projects  temp  test-copy.txt  test.txt


4.14.3 Moving and Renaming: The mv Command
The mv command moves files or folders to a new location. It’s also used to rename things!
To rename a file:
$ mv test-copy.txt renamed-file.txt
$ ls
Output:
README.txt  documents  documents-backup  music  pictures  projects  renamed-file.txt  temp  test.txt
The file test-copy.txt has been renamed to renamed-file.txt.
To move a file into a folder:
$ mv renamed-file.txt temp/
$ ls temp/
Output:
renamed-file.txt
The file has moved into the temp folder. Notice it’s no longer in our current directory.
You can move and rename at the same time:
$ mv test.txt documents/my-test-file.txt
$ ls documents/
Output:
my-test-file.txt  notes  reports  test.txt


4.14.4 Removing Files: The rm Command
The rm command removes (deletes) files. Be careful! There’s no “undo” or trash bin—deleted files are gone forever!
$ rm documents/my-test-file.txt
$ ls documents/
Output:
notes  reports  test.txt
To remove multiple files at once:
$ cd temp/
$ touch file1.txt file2.txt file3.txt
$ ls
Output:
file1.txt  file2.txt  file3.txt  renamed-file.txt
$ rm file1.txt file2.txt file3.txt
$ ls
Output:
renamed-file.txt
To remove a folder and everything inside it, use -r (recursive) and usually -f (force, to avoid confirmation prompts):
$ cd ..
$ rm -rf documents-backup
$ ls
Output:
README.txt  documents  music  pictures  projects  temp
Warning: rm -rf is very powerful and very dangerous! Always double-check what you’re deleting. There’s a famous joke: “To understand what rm -rf / does, try it!” Don’t actually try it—it would attempt to delete everything on your computer!


4.14.5 Removing Empty Folders: The rmdir Command
The rmdir command removes directories, but only if they’re empty:
$ cd temp/
$ rm renamed-file.txt
$ cd ..
$ rmdir temp
$ ls
Output:
README.txt  documents  music  pictures  projects
If you try to use rmdir on a folder that has files in it, you’ll get an error:
$ rmdir documents
Output:
rmdir: failed to remove 'documents': Directory not empty
For non-empty folders, use rm -rf instead.
crumbs: 4  4. Intro to Bash (and CLIs)

title: 4  4.  Intro to Bash (and CLIs)
section: 4.15 Reading Files: cat, less, and more
text:
4.15 Reading Files: cat, less, and more

4.15.1 The cat Command
The cat command displays the contents of a file. It’s short for “concatenate,” but most people use it to quickly view file contents:
$ cd documents/notes/
$ cat ideas.txt
Output:
(displays the contents of ideas.txt)
If the file is empty (like ours), you won’t see anything! Let’s add some content first using a different method:
$ echo "My brilliant idea: automated coffee maker" > ideas.txt
$ cat ideas.txt
Output:
My brilliant idea: automated coffee maker
You can also use cat to view multiple files:
$ echo "More ideas here!" > ideas2.txt
$ cat ideas.txt ideas2.txt
Output:
My brilliant idea: automated coffee maker
More ideas here!
Limitation of cat: If the file is very long, cat dumps everything to the screen at once, and you’ll need to scroll back up to see the beginning. For long files, use less or more.


4.15.2 The less Command
The less command shows file contents one page at a time, letting you scroll through:
$ less ideas.txt
When using less: - Arrow keys or spacebar to scroll down - b to scroll back up - / followed by text to search - q to quit
less is great for long files because you have full control over navigation.


4.15.3 The more Command
The more command is similar to less but older and simpler:
$ more ideas.txt
With more: - Spacebar to go to the next page - Enter to go down one line - q to quit
Difference between less and more: - less lets you scroll backward; more only goes forward - less has more features (searching, better navigation) - The joke: “less is more, and more is less!” (meaning less is actually more capable than more)
In practice, most people use less because it’s more flexible. But both do the job for viewing files!
crumbs: 4  4. Intro to Bash (and CLIs)

title: 4  4.  Intro to Bash (and CLIs)
text:
4.16 Quick Reference: Summary of Commands
Here’s a handy table of all the commands we covered:



Command
What It Does
Example




pwd
Print working directory (show where you are)
pwd


ls
List files and folders
ls -ltr


cd
Change directory (move to another folder)
cd documents


cd ..
Go up one directory level
cd ..


cd ~ or cd
Go to home directory
cd


mkdir
Make a new directory
mkdir new-folder


rmdir
Remove an empty directory
rmdir old-folder


touch
Create an empty file
touch file.txt


cp
Copy files or folders
cp file.txt copy.txt


cp -r
Copy a folder and all contents
cp -r folder/ backup/


mv
Move or rename files/folders
mv old.txt new.txt


rm
Remove files
rm file.txt


rm -rf
Remove folders and contents
rm -rf folder/


cat
Display file contents
cat file.txt


less
View file with scrolling
less file.txt


more
View file page by page
more file.txt
crumbs: 4  4. Intro to Bash (and CLIs)

title: 4  4.  Intro to Bash (and CLIs)
text:
4.17 Tips for Learning

Practice, practice, practice! The best way to learn Bash is to use it. Try the commands in the sample directory we provided.
Don’t be afraid to experiment in test folders. Just be careful with rm commands!
Use Tab completion: Start typing a file or folder name and press Tab. Bash will complete it for you! This saves time and prevents typos.
Use the up arrow to cycle through previous commands. This is super handy when you need to run the same command again.
Google is your friend: When you’re stuck, search for “bash how to [what you want to do]” and you’ll find lots of help.
crumbs: 4  4. Intro to Bash (and CLIs)

title: 4  4.  Intro to Bash (and CLIs)
text:
4.18 Next Steps
Once you’re comfortable with these basic commands, you might want to explore:

Redirecting output (> and >>)
Piping commands together (|)
Finding files (find command)
Searching within files (grep command)
Using wildcards (* and ?)
Running scripts (.sh files)
