title: 17  14.  Step 2: Installing the Node.js packages with npm
section: 17.3 run npm install to in stall the packages
text:
17.3 run npm install to in stall the packages
To install these packages, run the following command from the top level folder (i.e. the “root” folder) in the project. This command creates a new folder named “node_modules” and downloads the code for each package into that folder.
npm install
Note: You may see warnings when you run this command saying that some of the packages that you are trying to install have been deprecated. This is not a problem for us now. This usually happens because the packages listed in the package-lock.json files (which we discuss below) file are out of date. Keep reading …
crumbs: 17  14. Step 2: Installing the Node.js packages with npm

title: 17  14.  Step 2: Installing the Node.js packages with npm
text:
17.4 npm package version numbers
Every time an npm package is updated by the developers of the package a new “version number” is created for that new version of the package. When someone uses a package to write their software, they should record the version number of of the package that was used. This is important because sometimes later versions of the package might not work with the software that was written to use an older version of the package.
Package updates (and hence version numbers) fall into one of the following categories:

MAJOR updates: new features that are not necessarily totally compatible with existing software that used older versions of this package.
MINOR updates: new features that are intended to be backward-compatible with older versions
PATCH fixes: ie. bug fixes that are intended to be backward-compatible with older versions

The npm package version numbers reflect the type of changes that were made to the package since the last version. THe version numbers in the form: MAJOR_NUMBER.MINOR_NUMBER.PATCH_NUMBER
For example the version number 0.7.1 has

MAJOR_NUMBER 0
MINOR_NUMBER 7

PATCH_NUMBER 1

When a new version of a package is released, the major, minor and patch numbers in the version number are updated accordingly.
crumbs: 17  14. Step 2: Installing the Node.js packages with npm

title: 17  14.  Step 2: Installing the Node.js packages with npm
section: 17.5 using a “^” before a version number (e.g. “^1.1.2”)
text:
17.5 using a “^” before a version number (e.g. “^1.1.2”)
It is common for version numbers to be listed with “special characters” that direct npm to install possibly later versions of the package than the specified version.
For example, a caret, i.e. ^, before a version number, e.g. ^1.1.2 , directs npm to install “this version or a later version that has the same MAJOR number”. This is often desired since versions of a package that have the same MAJOR version number should be compatible with each other.
For example the following line:
    "@radix-ui/react-checkbox": "^1.1.2",`
indicates that this project requires version 1.1.2 or later of the package. However, this will only install the latest 1.X.X version. It will NOT install any version from 2.0.0 or later.
The logic for this is that the original developer of our project probably developed the code for the project using version 1.1.2 of the package. If in the future a new improved version 1.1.3 would be released to fix some bugs in the package then that version should be used instead of 1.1.2. The same would be true if even later versions of the package would be release such as 1.1.4 or 1.1.5 or even 1.2.0 - the latest of any 1.X.X version would be used.
However, if a new MAJOR version is released, e.g. 2.0.0 then that would NOT be used when doing npm install for this project. The reason is that a new MAJOR version is not guaranteed to work with code that was written for a prior MAJOR version number of the package.
crumbs: 17  14. Step 2: Installing the Node.js packages with npm

title: 17  14.  Step 2: Installing the Node.js packages with npm
section: 17.6 package-lock.json records the exact version numbers that were used
text:
17.6 package-lock.json records the exact version numbers that were used
As mentioned earlier, in theory, PATCH and MINOR updates to a package shouldn’t break code built and tested with an earlier version that shares the same MAJOR number. In practice, though, that’s not always true. To minimize potential issues, it’s best to install the project using the exact same package versions as those used by the original developer. Doing so ensures you’re working in the same environment and helps you avoid unexpected differences in behavior.
For this reason, when npm installs a package into the project, it records the EXACT version number that was installed into a file named package-lock.json. If the package-lock.json file exists then npm will install whatever version is registered in the package-lock.json file. However, if there is no package-lock.json file in a project then the rules stated above regarding which package is installed are followed. To be clear:
npm install will do the following:

If a package-lock.json file exists then the versions recorded in that file are downloaded to the node_modules folder.
If there is no package-lock.json file in the project then the versions of the packages as indicated in the package.json file are downloaded to the node_modules folder. Note that these could be later versions than the actual numbers listed in the file. For example if the package.json file lists version ^1.7.3 then the latest version number that still has a 1 in the first position will be installed. (see above for more info about version numbers in the package.json file)
crumbs: 17  14. Step 2: Installing the Node.js packages with npm

title: 17  14.  Step 2: Installing the Node.js packages with npm
section: 17.7 Deprecated warning messages when doing npm install
text:
17.7 Deprecated warning messages when doing npm install
You may have noticed above that when you ran npm install, you got warning messages saying that one or more packages have been “deprecated”. In npm, a deprecation warning can refer either to an entire package or, more commonly, to a specific version of a package. In most cases, it means that the maintainers recommend upgrading to a newer version because the version being installed is outdated, has known issues, or has been superseded. This could happen if the package-lock.json file that was in the git repo has versions of packages that had later releases of new versions after the package-lock.json was created.
This generally should not be a problem for a learning tutorial. However, if you are planning on using this code in “production” it is recommended that you delete the package-lock.json file and re-run npm install. This should install the later versions of those packages that may have fixed some bugs. Hoewver, be aware the the original developer did not use these new package versions and therefore the code you have might not work 100% as expected and you might need to spend a little time debugging and testing the application.
crumbs: 17  14. Step 2: Installing the Node.js packages with npm

title: 17  14.  Step 2: Installing the Node.js packages with npm
section: 17.8 Additional rules for package version numbers in package.json file
text:
17.8 Additional rules for package version numbers in package.json file
Above we discussed version numbers that start with a ‘^’. There are other types of “special characters” that affect which version of a package is actually installed. Below are the common forms with brief examples.
The following is a quick reference table. These are explained in more detail below.










Form
Example
Meaning






Exact
1.2.3
Only that version




Caret
^1.2.3
Non-breaking updates (same major)




Tilde
~1.2.3
Patch updates (same minor)




X-range
1.2.x, *
Wildcards




Hyphen
1.2.3 - 1.4.0
Inclusive range




Comparators
>=1.2.3 <2
Logical AND/OR with |   |




Pre-release
^2.0.0-rc.1
Includes matching prereleases




Tag
"latest", "next"
Registry dist-tag




Alias
npm:pkg@^1
Install another package under this name




Local file
file:../dir
From local disk




Workspace
workspace:*
Workspace package reference




Link
link:../dir
Symlink to local dir




Tarball URL
https://…/pkg.tgz
Install from remote tarball




Git
github:user/repo#tag
From VCS (branch/tag/commit)






17.8.1 1) Exact version number (no extra special characters)

1.2.3

{ "dependencies": { "lodash": "1.2.3" } }


17.8.2 2) Caret range (^) — allow non-breaking updates (same major) - discussed above
The idea of the ^ is to only allow newer versions that will not break existing code. In general this means it allows for newer versions that have the same major number. For example:

^1.2.3 → >=1.2.3 <2.0.0

However, if the major version is 0 (e.g. 0.2.3) the caret works a little differently. A major version 0 is intended to signal that the package is still experimental or under active development. Because the package is not considered stable, even small changes—like a minor or patch update—may break existing code.
For this reason, npm’s version range rules become more restrictive for major-zero versions: the ^ will only allow updates that keep the left-most non-zero digit the same. This prevents accidentally upgrading to a version that might introduce breaking changes. For example:

^0.2.3 → >=0.2.3 <0.3.0 (major=0 is special)

{ "dependencies": { "lodash": "^4.17.21" } }


17.8.3 3) Tilde range (~) — allow patch updates (same minor)

~1.2.3 → >=1.2.3 <1.3.0

{ "dependencies": { "lodash": "~4.17.0" } }


17.8.4 4) X-range / wildcard

1.2.x, 1.x, *

{ "dependencies": { "lodash": "1.2.x" } }


17.8.5 5) Hyphen range

1.2.3 - 1.4.0 → >=1.2.3 <=1.4.0

{ "dependencies": { "lodash": "4.17.0 - 4.17.21" } }


17.8.6 6) Comparator sets

Use >, >=, <, <= and combine with spaces (AND) or || (OR):

>=1.2.3 <2.0.0
^1.2 || ^2.0


{ "dependencies": { "lodash": ">=4.17.0 <5" } }


17.8.7 7) Pre-releases

Append identifiers like -alpha.1, -beta, etc.
Pre-release … Must match explicitly. A prerelease like ^2.0.0-beta.1 will not include the final 2.0.0 version unless the range explicitly allows it (per npm’s semver rules).

{ "dependencies": { "react": "^19.0.0-rc.0" } }


17.8.8 8) Tags (dist-tags)

Named pointers published to the registry: latest, next, beta, etc.

{ "dependencies": { "typescript": "next" } }


17.8.9 9) Aliases (npm:)

Install one package as another name.

{ "dependencies": { "lodash": "npm:lodash-es@^4.17.21" } }


17.8.10 10) Local paths

file: to a directory or tarball on disk.

{ "dependencies": { "my-lib": "file:../my-lib" } }


17.8.11 11) Workspace references (workspace:)

For npm workspaces; pin to a workspace package.

{ "dependencies": { "ui": "workspace:*" } }


17.8.12 12) Local links (link:)

Symlink to a local folder (similar to npm link).

{ "dependencies": { "tooling": "link:../tooling" } }


17.8.13 13) Tarball URLs

Remote .tgz URL.

{ "dependencies": { "mypkg": "https://example.com/mypkg-1.2.3.tgz" } }


17.8.14 14) Git references

Full or shorthand; may include #branch, #tag, or #commit.

{
  "dependencies": {
    "lib-ssh": "git+ssh://git@github.com/user/repo.git#main",
    "lib-https": "git+https://github.com/user/repo.git#v1.2.3",
    "gh-short": "github:user/repo#abc1234",
    "gl-short": "gitlab:user/repo#v1.0.0",
    "bb-short": "bitbucket:user/repo#develop"
  }
}
crumbs: 17  14. Step 2: Installing the Node.js packages with npm

title: 17  14.  Step 2: Installing the Node.js packages with npm
text:
17.9 Alternatives to npm
The npm is the tool used to install and manage these packages. However there are other competing “package manager” tools for “npm packages”. Currently available package manager tools are listed below. There are pros/cons to using each one:

npm – default with Node.js; biggest ecosystem. Slower than others.
Yarn – fast installs; good caching. Old v1 now legacy.
Yarn Berry – no node_modules; great for managing many packages together. Complex setup.
pnpm – space-efficient; strict resolution. Some tools misbehave.
Bun – ultra-fast; includes runtime. New and less stable.

If you’re just starting out, I recommend using npm (it’s most popular). However, don’t be surprised if some other tutorials that you see mention other package managers. All package managers for Javascript have similar capabilities and features.
crumbs: 17  14. Step 2: Installing the Node.js packages with npm

title: 17  14.  Step 2: Installing the Node.js packages with npm
text:
17.10 Alternatives to Node.js
Similarly there are Javascript “runtime” environments other than Node.js. Again - if you’re just starting out, I recommend that you use Node.js but be aware of the existance of the others.

Deno – modern and secure; runs JavaScript and TypeScript easily. Not all Node tools work yet.
Bun – very fast and all-in-one (includes tools for testing and building). Still quite new.
Cloudflare Workers – runs small apps close to users for speed. Can’t use all Node features.
Workerd – the open-source engine behind Cloudflare’s system. Mainly for advanced use.

title: 18  15.  Step 3: Storing your private info (env files, etc)
text:
18.1 More about the .env files
Private information such as passwords and API Keys (which we will discuss later) should never be stored in git because git repositories are often shared with other people. For similar reasons, passwords, API keys, etc. should also never by typed directly into Javascript code or code of any other programming language.
A typical web project requires different passwords, API keys, etc to allow integration with external services. In this project we will be integrating your NextJS app with Supabase, Google OAuth and the Chatgpt API. Each one of these integrations requires some sort of “secret” info (password, API Key, etc) to authenticate (i.e. login) to the remote system.
Much of this “secret” information will be stored in files whose filenames include “.env”. Remember that the .gitignore file identifies the files in your project that should never be committed to git. The .env files are prevented from being committed to git by referencing them in the .gitignore file.
In this project, we will need two different .env files. You will need to modify the contents of these .env files with the API keys that you generate for your Supabase account and other accounts.
The developer of this tutorial created one .env.example file. This is just an example file. It doesn’t contain real info. It should be copied into the locations for the .env files that we will be using.
For now, we will just copy the .env.exapmle file in the two locations. We will come back later and modify these files and explain more about them.
You need to create two local .env files for environment variables. These files will contain API keys and configuration that you’ll add throughout this tutorial. Note that the File names must be exact:

text:
If you want to see the frontend before connecting the backend:

Go to the GitHub repository commits tab
Scroll to the bottom and find the commit labeled “front end boilerplate”
Copy the commit hash
Check out that specific commit:

type git -v to see your git version
run ONE of the following command depending on your git version

git 2.23 and later: git switch --detach [commit-hash]
older versions of git: git checkout [commit-hash]


Run the development server:

npm run dev
This version has placeholder backend logic, allowing you to explore the UI without full functionality.

To get back to the latest version of the code run the following:

run ONE of the following command depending on your git version

git 2.23 and later:

git switch - or
git switch BRANCH_NAME (where BRANCH_NAME is the name of your branch such as master or main)

older versions of git:

git checkout - or
git checkout BRANCH_NAME (where BRANCH_NAME is the name of your branch such as master or main)

title: 20  17.  Step 5: Setup Supabase
text:
20.1 Remote vs. Local Supabase
Supabase is an online service that gives you the tools you need to store and manage data for your app. It includes:
Supabase can run remotely (hosted online by Supabase) and/or locally (running on your own computer). For beginners, remote Supabase is far easier. Everything happens in your browser, and nothing must be installed or configured. Local Supabase is mainly for advanced users and developers who want to test everything on their own computer before uploading to the Internet. Having a local copy of supabase also allows you to develop your app during times that you don’t have access to the Internet.
In this tutorial we will use remote Supabase only, so you do not need to install a local copy or manage anything technical on your machine.

title: 20  17.  Step 5: Setup Supabase
text:
20.2 Sign Up for Supabase

Go to the Supabase website
Sign up for a free account
Create a new project

title: 20  17.  Step 5: Setup Supabase
text:
20.3 Project Configuration
When creating your project, you’ll need to:

Choose a project name
Set a database password (save this securely)
Select a region (choose the closest to your users)

Important: Save your database password - you’ll need it later.

title: 20  17.  Step 5: Setup Supabase
text:
20.4 Get Your API Keys
Once your project is created:

Edit the .env.local file. It currently looks like this:

# You will need a .env.local file for local dev server (localhost)
# You will need a .env.test.local file for running the integration tests.

# Create the those files, and add the following variables.
# The local files are ignored by default.

# In .env.local and .env.test.local:
NEXT_PUBLIC_SUPABASE_URL="https://XXXX.supabase.co"
NEXT_PUBLIC_SUPABASE_ANON_KEY="XXXX"

# In addition to that, you also need .env.test.local with these variables:
SUPABASE_SERVICE_KEY="XXXX"
STRIPE_SECRET_KEY="sk_test_XXX"
STRIPE_PRICE_ID="price_XXX"
STRIPE_WEBHOOK_SECRET="whsec_XXX"```

Delete the bottom few lines and top few lines so that the file now looks like this:
# In .env.local and .env.test.local:
NEXT_PUBLIC_SUPABASE_URL="https://XXXX.supabase.co"
NEXT_PUBLIC_SUPABASE_ANON_KEY="XXXX"
Go to Project Settings (Gear button at bottom left of screen) → Data API
 Copy the URL.
Modify the following line in the .env.local file to reflect the URL that you copied.
NEXT_PUBLIC_SUPABASE_URL="https://XXXX.supabase.co"
Click on the API Keys section.
Copy the anon public key.

Modify the following line in the .env.local file to reflect the URL that you copied.
NEXT_PUBLIC_SUPABASE_ANON_KEY="XXXX"

title: 21  17b.  Step 5a: Supabase CLI command
text:
21.1 Installing the Supabase CLI
The supabase CLI is a command that you can run from your terminal to control and configure your Supabase server. The name of the command is appropriately “supabase”.
While, you can configure and manage your remote supabase server directly from the supabase website, it is often easier to use the supabase CLI command to perform much of the configuration and management of the supabase server.
Do not confuse the supabase CLI command with the supabase server. These are different products. Both can be installed locally.
There is more than one way to install the supabase CLI:
In the previous section you setup a Supabase project on the Supabase website. Supabase has many different features (database, authentication, edge functions, storage buckets, etc). You can configure most of what you need to configure by “clicking around” on the website. However, there are some things that cannot be done on the website. For these things we must use the “supabase CLI tool”.
In addition, using the supabase CLI command can often be easier and more efficient than accessing the same functionality via the Supabase website.

title: 21  17b.  Step 5a: Supabase CLI command
text:
21.2 Using Supabase CLI via npx
There are different options for installing/running the supabase CLI command. The simplest and easiest way to use the supabase command is to use the npx command to run the supabase command. npx (Node Package Executer) comes with Node.js. While the npm (Node Package Manager) tool can be used to download and install packages on your computer, the npx package is used to download and run the code from an npm package without actually “installing” the package on your computer.
For example the if you run the following command from the top level folder of your project, you will see a quite lengthy message that describes the different options you can use with the Supabse CLI tool. We will be covering some of the many options as we progress through this tutorial.
npx supabase --help

title: 21  17b.  Step 5a: Supabase CLI command
section: 21.3 Installing Supabase CLI on your computer
text:
21.3 Installing Supabase CLI on your computer
NOTE: remember that the supabase CLI is NOT the same as the supabase server. In this section we are discussing installing the supabase CLI on your local computer - not the supabase server. 

In this tutorial we will be using npx to run the supabase CLI. However there are some benefits to acutally “installing” the supabase command on your computer. If you use npx to run the supabase CLI, then every time you run the npx supabase command, the latest copy of the supabase npm package is downloaded to your computer. If you don’t have access to the Internet, things become more complicated. For this and other reasons, some people prefer to install the supabase CLI on their computer. You can do so by using one of the options listed below. Note that if you do install supabase on your computer then the command would simply be

supbase ...(other options)...

instead of

npx supabase ...(other options)....

See official instructions for how to install here: https://supabase.com/docs/guides/local-development/cli/getting-started The following summarizes your options to install locally:

Install the supabase CLI command as an npm package. To do so, run the following command from the root (top level folder) for your project:
npm install supabase --save-dev
NOTE: installing using the -g option to npm is no longer supported
You can also install the supabase CLI command on Mac by using the Homebrew package manager or on Windows by using the Scoop package manager. See the instructions here https://github.com/supabase/cli?tab=readme-ov-file to learn more about this option.
You can also download the actual program files from here: https://github.com/supabase/cli/releases. Be aware that this page lists “pre-release” versions as well as “release” versions. The “pre-release” versions may have the latest fixes and modifications but are not supported. For example, at the time of this writing the latest “release” version is 2.58.5 but there are “pre-release” versions 2.58.6, 2.59.*, 2.60.1, 2.60.2 Use the pre-release versions if you want the absolute latest features but be aware that they may not have been fully tested.

title: 21  17b.  Step 5a: Supabase CLI command
section: 21.4 How to use the supabase command via npm and npx
text:
21.4 How to use the supabase command via npm and npx
IMPORTANT: If you are using supabase cli via npm then you should prefix all uses of the supabase command with “npx” (see examples below). For example, the following command will show you which version of the supabase cli you are using:
npx supabase --version
The following gives you a very short summary for how to use the supabase command
npx supabase --help
npx is the Node Package eXecution command. This command can be used to run (or eXecute) a command that is installed as an npm package.

21.4.1 supabase ‘sub-commands’
The supabse command has numerous “sub commands”. For example:

npx supabase db is used to work with the Supabase database.
Run npx supabase db --help to get help specific to the db sub-command.
npx supabse functions is used to work with Supabase “edge functions”.
Run npx supabase functions --help to get help specific to the db sub-command.
etc.

The full official reference for how to use the supabase CLI command is here: https://supabase.com/docs/reference/cli/introduction There are many options and the official reference can be overwhelming. We will walk you through an introduction of using the supabase CLI command in this tutorial.

title: 21  17b.  Step 5a: Supabase CLI command
text:
21.5 Login in to Supabase
Run the following command:
npx supabase login

You should see the following: Hello from Supabase! Press Enter to open browser and login automatically.
Press Enter and a browser will open and display a code. Copy the code.
Go back to the terminal and enter the code and press Enter
You should now be logged into supabase.

title: 21  17b.  Step 5a: Supabase CLI command
section: 21.6 Get a list of your projects
text:
21.6 Get a list of your projects
Run the command npx supabase projects list to get a list of your supabase projects. Output should look similar to the following. Note that I modified the IDs shown below, as this info should be kept “secret”. This shows that my supabase setup currently has two different projects:
$ npx supabase projects list
Cannot find project ref. Have you run supabase link?

  
   LINKED | ORG ID               | REFERENCE ID         | NAME               | REGION                   | CREATED AT (UTC)    
  --------|----------------------|----------------------|--------------------|--------------------------|---------------------
          | bxcebkwgtuyzysrsyvsx | iswnysrsyqrpblgfvrar | supabase tutorial  | East US (North Virginia) | 2025-10-23 13:25:25 
          | bxcebkwgtuyzysrsyvsx | bvysrsysihcpsomfkyja | Supbase tutorial 3 | East US (North Virginia) | 2025-10-23 17:24:36

title: 21  17b.  Step 5a: Supabase CLI command
text:
21.7 Find your project’s reference ID
In the next step we will “link” the project on your computer to your Supabase project that you setup on the Supabase website. To do so, you will need to know your “project ref”. It is listed in the output of the npx supabase projects list command (see above). For example, the REFERENCE ID for the 2nd project listed above is bvysrsysihcpsomfkyja.
The project reference ID is also part of your project’s URL. You can find your project URL in your Supabase dashboard URL. It looks something like this: https://app.supabase.com/project/bvysrsysihcpsomfkyja The part after /project/ is your project ref, ie. in the example above this would be bvysrsysihcpsomfkyja. However, your own project-ref will obviously be different.

21.7.1 Link your project
Once you have identified your project ref, open your terminal, and navigate to your project directory. Then run the following command where “YOUR_PROJECT_REF” is replaced with your actual project ref. This command creates a connection between your local machine and your cloud project so that future commands from the CLI will knows which project you’re working with.
npx supabase link --project-ref YOUR_PROJECT_REF
For example, given the example above the command would be: The ouput shown below is what I got when I ran the command. This indicates that my project is linked with the remote supabase server. The WARNING that you see is harmless. Click on the link below to understand more about this warning message.

npx supabase link --project-ref bvysrsysihcpsomfkyja
Initialising login role...
Connecting to remote database...
Finished supabase link.
WARNING: Local database version differs from the linked project.
Update your supabase/config.toml to fix it:
[db]
major_version = 17






click for an explanation of the WARNING message





Developers often run a local version of the Supabase server that allows them to develop their project without having Internet access. When the developer wants to synchronize the work that they did on their local computer with the remote Supabase server, they can link their project to the remote project (as we did here) and then run the command npx supabase push to “push” their work to the remote server. For this to work correctly, the supabase version that is installed locally must be compatible with the supabase version on the remote server.
We decided that for simplicity, we will not use a local installation of the Supabase server. However, when this git repo was originally developed, the developer did have a local Supabase server installed on his computer. The file config.toml that is in the supabase folder stores configuration information for the local Supabase server. When this project was originally developed, the supabase/config.toml file got committed to git.
The warning message is simply saying that the recorded version of the local Supabase server not compatible with the version for remote Supabase server. However, as we said above, we are not using an actual local Supabase server. Therefore we can ignore this message. Alteratively, we can change the contents of the supabase/config.toml file by modifying the lines in the supabase/config.toml that record the local supabase version to read as follows:
[db]
major_version = 17







21.7.2 Test the link
You can run the following commands to test that your link has been established correctly.
The following should show all Supabase projects your CLI account has access to:
npx supabase projects list
The following should show whether your local directory is currently linked to a Supabase project:
npx supabase link status

title: 22  18.  Step 6: setup authentication (Google OAuth)
text:
22.1 Create a Google Cloud Project
This step connects your Supabase project with Google’s OAuth 2.0 service so users can log in using their Google accounts.
OAuth stands for “Open Authentication”. It is a standard that website owners can use to integrate with 3rd party services, such as Google, Github, etc, so that the users of the website can use their Google/Github/etc password to login.
From the perspective of our website, task-app, the code to do all this is run on the Supabase Servers. Therefore we will have to configure the Supabase Servers with the info necessary to make this happen.
In addition will will need to setup a Google Cloud Project here: https://console.cloud.google.com/. This is where you will need to setup Google to recognize your app and allow your users to login using their google accounts.
See this page for more information about setting up Google’s OAuth 2.0 service. https://developers.google.com/identity/protocols/oauth2/

title: 22  18.  Step 6: setup authentication (Google OAuth)
text:
Go to https://console.cloud.google.com/ and login with your google userid and password.

The rectangle in the upper left corner shows the project you are working on. If you’ve never used google cloud the box will say “Select a project” (as it does in the screenshot.) Click on the rectangle to select the project you want. See next step to create a new project.
To create a new project, click Create Project and give it a clear name

Enter a name for your project and click the create button.

Navigate to APIs & Services → Credentials.


Click Create Credentials → OAuth client ID to start generating keys.

title: 22  18.  Step 6: setup authentication (Google OAuth)
text:
22.2 Configure the OAuth Consent Screen
The flow takes a slightly different path if you’ve never setup Google OAuth for this project or if you have started to set it up before.

If this is the first time you’re setting up Google OAuth use the steps shown below.
If you started to setup Google OAuth below - skip to the next section.


22.2.1 First time setting up Google OAuth
Continue as shown below or start again from APIs & Services → OAuth consent screen.
This step can be accomplished in one of two ways. Read the following “Note”.






Note



If you followed all of the above steps, you should see the following screen. Click as shown below. (However, if you took a break from what you were doing you can continue by going to back to https://console.cloud.google.com/ and clicking on APIs & Services as shown in the next NOTE.










Note



If you took a break and came back, or you got lost, you can continue by going to back to https://console.cloud.google.com/ and clicking on APIs & Services as shown below.



 


22.2.2 If you’ve started to setup Google OAuth before

Navigate back to https://console.cloud.google.com/ and click on APIs & Services as shown below.

Then click on OAuth Consent Screen

title: 22  18.  Step 6: setup authentication (Google OAuth)
text:
22.3 Add your basic app info:
Whether this is the first time you are configuring Google OAuth, you should see one of the screens similar to those shown below.NOTE that if you have already started to configure Google OAuth before, you may need to click on the Branding option in the left hand menu (2nd choice from the top- see the blue oval in the picture). 
If you don’t see the info mentioned below, click on the different menu choices on the left hand side to search for where to enter the info below. Google often updates their website and the exact location for the info may have mooved by the time you read this.
The information that you fill out on this screen will affect what the users see when they try to “login with google”



You may see this





or may see this



22.3.1 App name
A name for your app (users will see this)


22.3.2 User support email
email for users to contact you with questions


22.3.3 Authorized domains
Under Authorized domains, add the domain used by your Supabase project. For example: bysrsyzsihcpsomfkyja.supabase.co You can get this from your Supabase dashboard. If you have been following this tutorial in order this info should also be in the .env.local file if you have in your top level folder for your project.


22.3.4 Audience
Under “Audience” choose External
This will allow you app to be viewed from anywhere in the world. However, your app must undergo review by Google before being allowed to use Google OAuth2 externally. Until then you can setup “test users” with google accounts. Only the specified “test users” will be allowed to “sign in with google” until your app has been reviewed by Google.
You will setup the test users later.
NOTE: You can only choose “Internal” if you’ve setup an organization with Google.


22.3.5 Developer Contact Information
Type an email address for Google to contact you for technical issues.


22.3.6 Click “Save”
Save and continue through the remaining steps.

title: 22  18.  Step 6: setup authentication (Google OAuth)
text:
22.4 Get Your OAuth Credentials

Return to APIs & Services → Credentials.
Click as below to create an OAuth 2.0 Client ID.

Choose Web application as the application type.
 You need to give a name to the application (Web client 1” in the screenshot below). This name is only used internal to the Google Cloud environment to refer to the application that you are setting up. This name will not appear anywhere to your users.
You then need to setup the URIs (i.e. URLs) that the Supabase servers will be contacted with from Google to indicate that the login was successful. You need to get this info from your Supabase configuration. This info was also saved in your .env.local file

Add your Supabase callback URL under Authorized redirect URIs: https://[your-project-ref].supabase.co/auth/v1/callback
You can get your-project-ref by doing one of the following:

logging into your Supabase account and getting this info from the Supabase settings.
You also can retreive it from the .env.local file that you had setup earlier. That file contained a line such as :

NEXT_PUBLIC_SUPABASE_URL=“https://dfdqbazsihcpsomfkyja.supabase.co”

In this example dfdqbazsihcpsomfkyja is your-project-ref. Therefore the Authorize redirect URI for this example is:

https://dfdqbazsihcpsomfkyja.supabase.co/auth/v1/callback

Obviously you will have a different project-ref and therefore a slightly different URL.

Click “Create button”
After creation, copy your Client ID and Client Secret. You WILL NOT BE ABLE TO GET THESE CODES AGAIN FROM GOOGLE. Store these codes in a safe place. DO NOT store these code in any files that will be committed to git.

title: 22  18.  Step 6: setup authentication (Google OAuth)
text:
22.5 Configure Google Auth in Supabase

Open your Supabase dashboard.
Navigate to Authentication → Providers.
Select Google.
Paste your Client ID and Client Secret.
Click Save to enable Google login for your project.


With this configuration complete, Supabase can now handle secure login flows using Google OAuth.

title: 23  19.  Step 7: Set Up OpenAI API
text:
23.1 Create OpenAI Account
Click here https://platform.openai.com/docs/quickstart for the OpenAI official quickstart guide.
See below for step by step instructions.
crumbs: 23  19. Step 7: Set Up OpenAI API

title: 23  19.  Step 7: Set Up OpenAI API
text:
Go to the OpenAI Platform: https://platform.openai.com/
Sign up or log in to your account.
Open the Dashboard (or click on the gear for settings)
crumbs: 23  19. Step 7: Set Up OpenAI API

title: 23  19.  Step 7: Set Up OpenAI API
text:
23.2 Create a “project” (optional)
All OpenAI API keys are associated with a “project”. You automatically have one “Default Project”. However, it can be helpful to create a new OpenAI “project” for every website or other product you are creating.
OpenAI “projects” allow for more control as to how your API Keys are used.
When you use a “project” …

you can have several people in your team share the API Key
you can set more fine grained permissions as to how the project can use the key

See here for more info about Open AI projects: https://help.openai.com/en/articles/9186755-managing-projects-in-the-api-platform
To create a project, do the following:

23.2.1 Click settings (gear) button



23.2.2 Select “projects”



23.2.3 Click “create”



23.2.4 Give your project a name
crumbs: 23  19. Step 7: Set Up OpenAI API

title: 23  19.  Step 7: Set Up OpenAI API
text:
23.3 Create API keys

23.3.1 Click API Keys



23.3.2 Click Create new secret key.



23.3.3 Key Owner - “YOU” or a “SERVICE ACCOUNT”
When creating the key you need to specify whether the key is owned by “you” or by a “service account”. See more explanation below.
 
API Keys that are owned directly by “you” are useful when you are performing experiments with AI or just getting to understand how things work. In addition some 3rd part websites ask you to upload an OpenAI API key so that the work that they do for you is billed to YOUR OpenAI API key - i.e. the service doesn’t pay for the AI processing it does on your behalf, you do. It makes sense for these types of keys to be owned by “You”.
However, when creating software products that use API Keys it’s recommended to create a “Service Account” for that product and have the key be owned by that service account. The use of the key can then be tracked to your product’s “service account”.

Setting permissions for keys owned by “You”
If you create a key that is owned by “You” (see above) then you are given the opportunity to set permissions that govern what is and what isn’t allowed to be done with the key. This is especially important if you are going to be using your API Key to access 3rd party services. You can restrict the API Key to only allow some features to ensure that the 3rd party service doesn’t abuse the use of the key (as use of the API key would be charged to you).
If you create a key that is owned by a “Service Account” (as recommended for this project) then you can set permissions


Setting permissions for keys owned by a “Service Account”
By contrast, the permissions for a key that is owned by a “Service Account” are governed by the service account’s “role”. To change what the key can do, you must change the service account’s roles/permissions, not the key. We’ll see below (after saving the key) how to modify the permissions for such a key.



23.3.4 Copy the key immediately — you won’t be able to see it again.
When you click “create secret key” (see above) you will be shown the actual key. Copy the key immediately and save it — you won’t be able to see it again.
The key should be treated in the same way as a password. (In the following screenshot the API Key is purposely obscured). It is secret information which should never be divulged to anyone outside of your organization. Even within your organization, only people who have a “need to know” should be given access to the actual key value. Therefore do NOT commit this to git because git repos are often shared with people who should not have access to this type of info.

In the next section we will explain how to store this API Key in the supabase/.env file. This is because the communication with OpenAI will be done via a Supabase Edge Function. Much of the other “secret” information that we will be using in this tutorial will also be stored in .env files (see the section above that describes more about .env files).
For now, I recommend that for the purposes of this tutorial, you also store all of the secret info in a Word document (or similar). This is NOT the recommended approach for actual software development projects. However, as you are learning it can be helpful to have one file that stores all of the “secret information” in one place. You can store notes and screenshots in this file that help you remember where you got the information (e.g. OpenAI) and what it will be used for.
crumbs: 23  19. Step 7: Set Up OpenAI API

title: 23  19.  Step 7: Set Up OpenAI API
section: 23.4 Setting permissions for keys owned by a “Service Account”
text:
23.4 Setting permissions for keys owned by a “Service Account”
How to adjust permissions:
Go to Organization → Admin keys / Service accounts.
Select the service account.
Modify its assigned roles/permissions.
All keys for that service account will now reflect those updated permissions.
If you’d like, I can outline how to set up a more restrictive service account.

23.4.1 Store as Supabase Secret
You’ll configure your Edge Functions to read OPENAI_API_KEY from the Supabase environment.

Install Supabase CLI (if you haven’t already)
(see the chapter above about the Supabase CLI)
Link your local project to your Supabase project (if you haven’t already)
(see the chapter above about the Supabase CLI)
Run the following command to set the secret in Supabase, where “your-openai-key” is the tet of the key that you just got from openai
supabase secrets set OPENAI_API_KEY=your-openai-key
Confirm that the key was set:
You can run the following command to confirm that there is an OPENAI_API_KEY set to some value. However, the “DIGEST” that is shown here is NOT the actual key. This is done for security reasons. You can delete the key and reset it but you cannot see the actual value for the key.

npx supabase secrets list
NAME           | DIGEST                                                           
----------------|------------------------------------------------------------------
 OPENAI_API_KEY | 661627b246146bfd00805f19997db43c066fba3002fabe2ed6a9922c8db29f87 

You can also use the supabase website dashboard (Project Settings → API → Secrets) to see the same info.
crumbs: 23  19. Step 7: Set Up OpenAI API

title: 24  20.  Step 8: Set Up Stripe
text:
24.1 Create Stripe Account
Stripe will handle subscriptions and billing. You’ll run in Test Mode while developing.

title: 24  20.  Step 8: Set Up Stripe
text:
Go to https://stripe.com.
Sign up for a new account or log in.

title: 24  20.  Step 8: Set Up Stripe
text:
24.2 The Stripe Sandbox
When you first start using Stripe you will be in “Sandbox” mode. This means that real cards are never charged. However, you can use “fake” credit cards (see below) to make sure that your code works.

title: 24  20.  Step 8: Set Up Stripe
text:
24.3 Get API Keys
Click on the “Home” menu (you should be there when you start).
The API keys should be listed (search for API on the page).


Add the publishable key to your Next.js environment:
# .env.local
NEXT_PUBLIC_STRIPE_PUBLISHABLE_KEY=your-publishable-key
Store the secret key in Supabase (for Edge Functions):
npx supabase secrets set STRIPE_SECRET_KEY=your-secret-key
If you have a separate dev/prod project, repeat this setup per environment (we do not in this tutorial).


24.3.1 Create a Product

In Stripe dashboard, go to Product Catalog > All Products.
Click + Create product.
Fill in:

Name (e.g., “Pro Plan”)
Optional description and image.

Under Pricing, create a price:

Recurring
Billing period: Monthly
Amount: e.g., $10

Save the product and its price.
Copy the Price ID (e.g., price_12345...).
Add the Price ID to your app’s config (e.g., environment variable or constants file), for example: .env.local
NEXT_PUBLIC_STRIPE_PRICE_ID=your-price-id



24.3.2 Get Webhook Signing Secret
You’ll use a webhook to let Stripe notify your app about subscription changes.

Go to Developers → Webhooks in Stripe.
Click + Add endpoint.
For now, you can use a temporary URL (you’ll update it later), such as: https://mybogusurl.com/ 
Under Select events to send, add:

checkout.session.completed
customer.subscription.updated
customer.subscription.deleted

Save the endpoint.
Stripe will show a Signing secret (e.g., whsec_...). Copy it.
Store it as a Supabase secret:
supabase secrets set STRIPE_WEBHOOK_SECRET=your-webhook-secret

title: 25  21.  Step 9: Set Up Supabase Database
text:
Your project ships with migrations that define the database schema and policies.

25.0.1 Run Database Migrations

Ensure you’re in the project root (where supabase/config.toml lives).
Run:
supabase db push







Note



There is a bug in the current code. When running the above command you will probably see the following errors.
$ npx supabase db push
Initialising login role...
Connecting to remote database...
Do you want to push these migrations to the remote database?
 • 0_init_profile.sql
 • 1_init_tasks.sql
 • 2_init_auth.sql
 • 3_init_storage_schema.sql
 • 4_init_usage_tracking.sql
 • 5_init_task_limit_triggers.sql
 • 6_init_account_tier_triggers.sql
 • 7_init_stripe_integration.sql

 [Y/n] y
 
Applying migration 0_init_profile.sql...
NOTICE (42710): extension "uuid-ossp" already exists, skipping

Applying migration 1_init_tasks.sql...
ERROR: function uuid_generate_v4() does not exist (SQLSTATE 42883)
At statement: 0                                                   
-- Tasks table                                                    
create table public.tasks (                                       
  task_id uuid default uuid_generate_v4() primary key,            
                       ^                                          
Try rerunning the command with --debug to troubleshoot the error.
This is caused by the file: supabase/migrations/1_init_tasks.sql
The file contains a call to the function: uuid_generate_v4().
This function should not be used any longer. Rather replace the call to that function with a call to the function gen_random_uuid(). Save the file and try the npx supabase db push again.



Wait for the migration to complete without errors.
In the Supabase dashboard, open Table Editor to confirm the tables exist.




25.0.2 Enable Row Level Security (RLS)
The migrations typically turn on RLS and define policies, so that:

Users can only read/update rows where user_id = their auth user id.
Anonymous users cannot access private data.
System operations (e.g., via service role) can bypass restrictions where needed.

You can verify policies under Database → Policies in the Supabase dashboard.
crumbs: 25  21. Step 9: Set Up Supabase Database

title: 26  22.  Step 10: Set Up Supabase Storage Bucket
text:
You’ll store task images in Supabase Storage.

26.0.1 Create Storage Bucket

In Supabase dashboard, go to Storage → Buckets.
Click New bucket.
Name it task-images (or whatever your code expects).
For this tutorial, set the bucket to Public.
Create the bucket.



26.0.2 Configure Bucket Settings
File size limit:

Decide on an appropriate max file size (e.g., 1 MB).
Enforce this in your upload UI and/or server-side logic.

Allowed file types:

Restrict to images:

image/jpeg
image/png
image/gif
image/webp


Access settings:

Public bucket:

Anyone with the URL can view the image (simpler for tutorials).

For production:

Consider a private bucket + signed URLs for more control.




26.0.3 Set Storage Policies
In the Policies section for your task-images bucket, ensure:

Authenticated users can upload files (e.g., policy: if auth.role() = 'authenticated').
Anyone can read files (for public tutorials).
Users can delete only their own images (e.g., match user_id in metadata/path).

You can either: - Use the provided migration policies, or - Create them via the Supabase dashboard policy builder.
crumbs: 26  22. Step 10: Set Up Supabase Storage Bucket

title: 27  23.  Step 11: Deploy Supabase Edge Functions
text:
Edge Functions are serverless handlers for AI, billing, and webhooks.
Location in project: supabase/functions/

27.0.1 The Three Functions

1. createTaskWithAI
Used to:

Accept task input (e.g., title, description).
Call OpenAI using OPENAI_API_KEY.
Generate or refine a label.
Insert/update the task row in the tasks table.

This function typically: - Validates the user (via JWT). - Checks subscription status if needed (e.g., premium-only features).


2. createStripeSession
Used to:

Create Stripe Checkout sessions for new subscriptions.
Return a customer portal link if the user already has a subscription.
Redirect users to Stripe when they click “Manage Subscription”.

It uses STRIPE_SECRET_KEY and price IDs to build sessions.


3. stripe-webhook
Used to:

Receive event notifications from Stripe.
Verify the webhook signature using STRIPE_WEBHOOK_SECRET.
Sync subscription status (e.g., set user_subscriptions.status = 'active').
Handle cancellations, renewals, and trial endings.

This function is called directly by Stripe, so it doesn’t use user JWTs.



27.0.2 Deploy the Functions
From your project root, deploy each function with the Supabase CLI:
# Deploy the AI task creation function
supabase functions deploy createTaskWithAI

# Deploy the Stripe session function
supabase functions deploy createStripeSession

# Deploy the webhook function
supabase functions deploy stripe-webhook
After deploying, the CLI will output function URLs like:
https://[your-project-ref].supabase.co/functions/v1/createTaskWithAI
Keep these handy for testing or local development.


27.0.3 Verify Deployment

In Supabase dashboard, open Edge Functions.
Confirm you see:

createTaskWithAI
createStripeSession
stripe-webhook

Click each function:

Check the Logs tab for any runtime errors.
Trigger test requests (e.g., via curl or a REST client) if needed.




27.0.4 Configure Stripe Webhook
stripe-webhook must accept unauthenticated calls from Stripe.

In Supabase dashboard, click the stripe-webhook function.
Go to the Details tab.
Find Function configuration (or Settings).
Disable Enforce JWT verification for this function.
Save the changes.

Why? Stripe does not send JWTs; the function instead authenticates via STRIPE_WEBHOOK_SECRET.


27.0.5 Update Stripe Webhook URL
Now point Stripe to your deployed function.

In Stripe Dashboard, go to Developers → Webhooks.
Click your webhook endpoint.
Update the Endpoint URL to:
https://[your-project-ref].supabase.co/functions/v1/stripe-webhook
Save the endpoint.
Use the Send test event button in Stripe to verify that your function:

Receives the event.
Validates the signature.
Updates your database correctly.
crumbs: 27  23. Step 11: Deploy Supabase Edge Functions

title: 28  24.  Step 12: Run the Application
text:
Now that the backend is configured, you can run the Next.js app locally.

28.0.1 Start the Development Server
From your project root:
npm install
npm run dev
The app usually runs at http://localhost:3000.
If you’re using pnpm or yarn, adjust accordingly.


28.0.2 Test Core Functionality
Walk through the main user flow to confirm everything is wired up correctly.
1. Authentication

Click “Sign in with Google” (or your configured provider).
Complete the OAuth flow.
Ensure you’re redirected to the dashboard.
In Supabase Auth → Users, verify your user was created.

2. Task Management

From the dashboard, create a new task (title + description).
Confirm:

The task appears in your list.
The AI-generated label is visible (or applied shortly after creation).

Check the tasks table in Supabase to see the new row.

3. Image Uploads

Edit a task and upload an image.
Confirm:

The file appears in the task-images bucket.
The image is displayed in the app (using the public URL).

Try uploading an invalid file type or large file to see error handling.

4. User Profile

Navigate to your profile page.
Check:

Basic account information is correct.
The task count or other stats update as you add/remove tasks.


5. Subscription Management

Click “Manage Subscription” or equivalent button.
Confirm:

You’re redirected to a Stripe-hosted checkout page.
The price and product name are correct.

Use a Stripe test card (e.g., 4242 4242 4242 4242) with:

Any future expiry date.
Any 3-digit CVC.
Any billing info.

Complete checkout and return to the app.
Verify:

Your user_subscriptions row is updated to active.
Premium-only features (if any) unlock.


6. Sign Out

Click “Sign out” or “Log out.”
Confirm:

You’re redirected back to the login page.
Protected routes are no longer accessible without signing in again.

title: 29  25.  Step 13: Deploy to Production
text:
Once everything works locally, you can deploy the frontend.

29.0.1 Deploying the Frontend
Recommended: Vercel
Vercel is tightly integrated with Next.js and offers smooth deployments.

Push your code to a Git repository (e.g., GitHub).
In Vercel, click New Project → Import from your repo.
During setup:

Select the correct framework: Next.js.
Add all required environment variables:

NEXT_PUBLIC_SUPABASE_URL
NEXT_PUBLIC_SUPABASE_ANON_KEY
NEXT_PUBLIC_STRIPE_PUBLISHABLE_KEY
any other NEXT_PUBLIC_... or server-side variables.


Deploy the app.

After deployment:

Visit the production URL to confirm it loads.
Test login, task creation, and subscription flows in production.

Alternative Options
If you prefer other providers:

Netlify – good Next.js support (with appropriate adapters).
AWS Amplify, Render, or any provider that supports Node/Next.js.

Configuration will be similar: point to your repo and set env vars.


29.0.2 Update Environment Variables for Production
For the production instance, make sure to:

Use your production Supabase project URL and anon/service keys.
Switch Stripe from test mode to live mode when ready:

Replace pk_test_... and sk_test_... with pk_live_... / sk_live_....
Update webhook endpoints/secrets accordingly.

Update OAuth redirect URIs:

Add your production domain (e.g., https://yourapp.com) in Google OAuth and Supabase Auth settings.

Configure CORS and allowed redirect URLs in Supabase to include the production domain.

title: 30  26.  Step 14: Extending the functionality
text:
30.1 Project Structure
At this point, you have a full-stack SaaS application with:
From here, you can refine the front end (i.e. Next.JS) to your liking, add features, harden security and observability to take the app into production. Ideas to grow your SaaS:
You can also use this tutorial as a framework to help you develop a brand new different application from scratch.
Here’s a quick overview of the main folders and what you typically edit:
To extend functionality:

title: 30  26.  Step 14: Extending the functionality
text:
├── app/                     # Next.js app routes and pages
├── components/              # Reusable React UI components
├── hooks/                   # Client logic and Supabase integration
├── supabase/
│   ├── functions/           # Edge functions (backend logic)
│   └── migrations/          # Database schema and configurations
└── tests/
    └── integration/         # Integration test suite


UI changes:
Update layout, pages, and routing in app/ and shared UI in components/.
Client logic:
Modify data fetching, hooks, and client-side behavior in hooks/.
Backend logic:
Add or update Edge Functions in supabase/functions/ for new APIs or integrations.
Database changes:
Create new migration files in supabase/migrations/ to add tables, columns, or policies.

title: 31  27.  Step 15: Automated Testing and Troubleshooting
text:
31.0.1 Integration Tests
Automated tests help ensure everything works after changes.
The project includes integration tests that talk to your real Supabase project (usually in a separate test environment).
crumbs: 31  27. Step 15: Automated Testing and Troubleshooting

title: 31  27.  Step 15: Automated Testing and Troubleshooting
text:
31.1 Troubleshooting
A few quick checks for common problems.

31.1.1 Environment Variables Not Loading

Verify the filenames:

Local Next.js: .env.local
Supabase: supabase/.env (if applicable) and Supabase secrets.

Restart the dev server after any env changes.
Confirm the variables are defined in:

The Next.js runtime (console.log(process.env.NEXT_PUBLIC_... )).
Supabase dashboard (for secrets).




31.1.2 Authentication Errors

Ensure your OAuth redirect URIs match exactly in:

Google Cloud Console (OAuth credentials).
Supabase Auth settings.

Make sure the Supabase Site URL matches your local and production URLs.
Inspect the browser network tab for auth-related errors.



31.1.3 Edge Functions Failing

Check that all required secrets are set (OPENAI_API_KEY, STRIPE_SECRET_KEY, STRIPE_WEBHOOK_SECRET).
In Supabase:

Open Edge Functions → Logs to see runtime errors.

Make sure code imports are correct and dependencies are installed.



31.1.4 Stripe Webhook Not Working

Confirm JWT verification is disabled for stripe-webhook.
Double-check the webhook URL in Stripe:

It must match the function URL exactly (including https).

Ensure the Signing secret in Supabase matches the current secret shown in Stripe.
Use Stripe’s Send test event to debug.



31.1.5 Database Errors

Ensure supabase db push ran successfully without errors.
Check that RLS policies allow the operation you’re trying.
Confirm that the user is authenticated when performing actions that require auth.
Inspect Supabase logs or use the SQL editor to run queries manually.
crumbs: 31  27. Step 15: Automated Testing and Troubleshooting

Overview of no-code/low-code workflow automation tools – e.g. make, n8n, zapier, gumloop (new AI first approach), connect common tools without writing full software applications.
Rapid development when compared with custom coded apps but can be more expensive to run. Great for prototyping or getting out version 1 of complicated apps. Can also be used in production but at much higher (sometimes prohibitive) cost.

title: 36  17.  Overview of HTML, CSS, JavaScript
text:
36.1 Intro to “Developer Tools” in the Browser
Modern browsers (Chrome, Edge, Firefox) include powerful developer consoles: - Elements: Inspect and edit HTML/CSS.
- Console: Execute JavaScript commands interactively.
- Network: Monitor API calls and performance.
- Sources: Debug scripts and set breakpoints.
- Application: View storage, cookies, and local data.
Understanding these tools is essential for integrating and debugging AI-powered web applications.

title: 38  19.  Measures of well designed programs
text:
The following are some metrics that can be used to see if a program is designed well:

Cyclomatic Complexity: Measures independent execution paths in a function. Lower is better.
Code Coverage: % of code exercised by automated tests. Aim ≥ 80%.
Coupling and Cohesion:

Coupling: how interdependent modules are (lower is better)
Cohesion: how focused a module’s responsibilities are (higher is better)

Lines of Code (LOC) per Method/Class: Monitors size; excessively large methods or classes often signal poor abstraction.
Maintainability Index: Combines LOC, complexity, and comment density into a single score.
Defect Density: Bugs per thousand lines of code; fewer indicates higher-code quality.
Technical Debt Ratio: Estimated “remediation cost” vs. development cost; lower ratios are healthier.
Static Analysis Warnings: Number/severity of linter or analyzer alerts per 1,000 LOC.
Code Churn: Frequency and volume of changes; high churn may signal instability or unclear design.
Documentation Coverage: Ratio of documented public APIs to total; measures how well the codebase is described.
